Advice.heading: ViCase Tiny: When space is premium
Advice.content: Choose this case only when space is at an absolute premium. Examples would be wall-mount presentation screens where you mount ViCase Tiny between display and wall or under the screen. If you plan to place your ViCase behind your display on the table, consider ViCase Mini. It is taller, but you would not be able to see that anyways and for the same money you will get more options.

Advice.heading: ViCase Mini: The default choice
Advice.content: This is the standard housing that gets most jobs done. With 4L it is still tiny, yet offers lots of upgradeability options. ViCase Mini supports up to i7 quad core and two 2.5i drives. More than enough for most use cases.

Advice.heading: ViCase Ultra: The powerhouse
Advice.content: For the ultimate performance ViCase Ultra offers all of ViCase Mini with the following Step-Up Features

Maximum number of 8 Bays. Each of the two bays under the Motherboard can be populated with either mSATA Adapter or 2.5" Disks.Two optional Disk Carrier are available. The 2.5" Disk Carrier can take up to 6 Disks. The 3.5" Disk carrier supports up to 3 disks.
HDD are mounted with vibration and shock insulating rubber grommets.

The two bay systems have two methods of cooling: 1) The disks under motherboard are use thermal conductive sponge that transfers heat of disks to Aluminum bottom cover that doubles as heat sink. 2) The Disk Carrier System comes with its own Fan and airflow guides. Fan speed can be regulated and monitored.

Advice.heading: Entry AMD
Advice.content: Choose this motherboard if lowest power consumption is most important. You have CPU choices of 12 and 25W. The lowest Intel CPU choice is 35W. But since the Motherboard chip is integrated in AMD AM1 and not integrated in Intel CPUs your power consumption comparison is 12W versus 48W. Keep in mind though that maximum performance of Entry AMD line is limited to about the performance level of a tablet. In some countries Entry AMD is half the cost for motherboard and CPU when compared to Entry Intel. In other countries the cost is the same.

Advice.heading: About Intel MotherBoards
Advice.content: Intel CPUs span the range from entry level (Celeron) to High End (i7), all using the same socket LGA 1150. This means you can start with an entry level CPU and upgrade your CPU later. All selected motherboards feature the LGA 1150, as such they all can take the i7 CPU. What makes a difference in motherboard features are the performance of connected accessories. Such as how many disks, RAID, maximum memory clock, etc. This motherboard directly supports UHD = 4k Display. Only at 30 Hz, but will be sufficient for high end picture frame.

Advice.heading: Entry Intel
Advice.content: Lowest cost Intel Motherboard. Comes with all basic features, such as 2 Disks, 16 MHz DDR3. 3 Display supported, resolution up to HD = 1920 x 1080 @ 60Hz

Advice.heading: Mid Range Intel
Advice.content: All features if Entry Intel plus step up features: Much faster Disk performance by supporting RAID 5 and Hybrid Disk. Build in high speed WiFi.

Advice.heading: High End Intel
Advice.content: All features if Entry Intel plus step up features: Double Memory Speed, Support for Overclocking, Support for UHD Displays = 3840 x 2160 @ 60Hz.
